update.description:
Script to use the python client to send the 'in progress' status to bitbucket.

[Tested on a new PR](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/18/issue_8_2_scpeters/diff) sent against my fork of sdformat.

Before accepting the PR when need to think about how to handle the packages that did not setup the bitbucket status via bitbucket_osrf user.

Investigating this problem now. Should be fixed now  cb1c75f . ~~Seems~~ It is a problem in bitbucket code, [my patch is being merged](https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/python-bitbucket/issues/35/current-code-does-not-respect-the-url-for).

* [https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/\_jrivero_/sdformat/commit/821a5e9872af/statuses/build](https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/_jrivero_/sdformat/commit/821a5e9872af/statuses/build)

I assume you just need to put a different link in there?

pull_request.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

pullrequest.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

content.raw:
Thanks for pointing this out. The logic is not trivial, works in this way:

 * If any of the package supplied in the list has never been installed, a message is displayed in stderr
 * if any of the packages is or has been installed in the system:
     * A header is displayed (with columns titles)
     * Each of the packges is marked at the begging with: ^in (installed) or ^rc | ^un (not installed now)

I have a working implementation, let me upload it.
content.html:
Thanks for pointing this out. The logic is not trivial, works in this way:

  • If any of the package supplied in the list has never been installed, a message is displayed in stderr
  • if any of the packages is or has been installed in the system:
    • A header is displayed (with columns titles)
    • Each of the packges is marked at the begging with: ^in (installed) or ^rc | ^un (not installed now)

I have a working implementation, let me upload it.

pull_request.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

pullrequest.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

content.raw: Oh, I didn't realize this was about triggering new builds. I intended my comment to be about reporting build status for all builds that are run, even if they were triggered from a timer or something.
content.html: Oh, I didn't realize this was about triggering new builds. I intended my comment to be about reporting build status for all builds that are run, even if they were triggered from a timer or something.

pull_request.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

pullrequest.title: Set inprogress status in bitbucket when building is ongoing

content.raw: My intention is to start using our infrastructure between bitbucket <-> jenkins already in place which currently covers PRs. We will need to modify the hooks so every commit is sent to the daemon and start building on every commit, which will generates an overload (imaging gazebo) that will impact the jenkins times.
content.html: My intention is to start using our infrastructure between bitbucket <-> jenkins already in place which currently covers PRs. We will need to modify the hooks so every commit is sent to the daemon and start building on every commit, which will generates an overload (imaging gazebo) that will impact the jenkins times.

content.raw:
Do we need to limit to the `-ci-pr_any-` jobs? It could be nice to have build status for default and release branch jobs too. For example, appveyor gives build status that is viewable on the commits page in a nice way:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/all
content.html:
Do we need to limit to the -ci-pr_any- jobs? It could be nice to have build status for default and release branch jobs too. For example, appveyor gives build status that is viewable on the commits page in a nice way:

  • https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/all

content.raw: Is this right? It seems to me that the old logic was correct, ie. if any of the needed packages match `^un`, then some of them are no installed, and should be installed.
content.html: Is this right? It seems to me that the old logic was correct, ie. if any of the needed packages match ^un, then some of them are no installed, and should be installed.
